review_text: "Perception is real, the truth is not." Lauren Greenfield's elegantly crafted doc about the political dynasty in the Philippines. Another maddening look at how those with wealth and power will never give it up, coming up with new ways to maintain their dominant command of power. One of these films that just makes me so angry about how much wealth rules the world and how they manipulate the masses so much (to be in their favor). And keep getting away with it. I like the way this doc is put together, it has a more compelling narrative than her last film Generation Wealth, but is just as fascinating to watch.

"Perception is real, and the truth is not". These terrifying words come from the delusional Imelda Marcos, whose influence on politics in the Philippines is scary. The Kingmaker interviews Marcos at length, only for it to become clear that she is a greedy liar seeking to play the victim. Her opulent lifestyle and desire to birth a paradise is slowly realised to come from a scary place. As The Kingmaker is mostly a conventional documentary, aside from its lack of chronology, it feels likely to become a neoliberal piece of mild condemnation without the guts to pick apart Filipino politics. Yet The Kingmaker does find a voice, and manages to find fault in the more liberal governments in the Philippines. Their inability to solve the problems are shown by the film's eventual focus on the resurgence of the Marcos family and their proxy candidate, the evil Rodrigo Duterte. It is a sad and scary time for the Philippines and really this story is still breaking. Who knows if The Kingmaker is telling this slice of history at its beginning or end.There's horrifying moments in The Kingmaker, such as the chilling accounts of torture, the children who openly like martial law, and the fact that Rodrigo Duterte has any power. As a documentary this may not be very inspired, but the subject matter is vital for us all to know. The inbreeding nature of politics has allowed one family to have influence, either overtly or covertly, over an entire country for decades. Perhaps Imelda Marcos does have a plan for paradise, but is the path to it justifiable?2019 Ranked

Lauren Greenfield ("The Queen of Versailles," "Generation Wealth") has once again proven why she's my favorite documentary filmmaker, and one of my favorite filmmakers, period. She explores new territory in "The Kingmaker," without straying away from her signature "photographic" and intimate style; the DNA of her style is felt and serves as a backbone to new elements that elevate it to another level in order to successfully cover the story of Imelda Marcos and politics in The Philippines. Everything I admire about her body of work is present on this one: Metaphors of excess and unbalance and its consequences; glamour and its beauty, but also how comical it can be; the obsession with material things and its demons. However, due to the nature of the subject, it goes a step further, diving into political territory and giving us a cautionary tale about power and greed that is harsh, timely, but hopeful. This project might not have been the culmination of 25 years of work like "Generation Wealth," but it's probably the most challenging one Greenfield has had to make. The challenges of this five-year endeavor are seen and felt on the screen, but they pay off. If Greenfield and her team were able to accomplish this, then I cannot wait to see what's next in store.I highly recommend this documentary: A portrait of a woman in and out of power; of a country in and out of justice; of a political system in and out of the past. If you're in LA or New York, make sure you catch it in theaters starting November 8th.

A worthy introduction to the madness that is Philippine politics. It's a crash course on the Marcoses and one of the darkest eras in the Philippines. While its attempt at weaving the incumbent leadership with the Marcos dynasty can at times be a stretch, as a Filipino, I can see how this might be the image that non-Filipinos have of the Philippines.As with most films and rooms that she inhabits, Imelda Marcos is magnetic. She's a modern-day Rasputin, who can hypnotize people and place them under her spell. Perhaps it is not the filmmaker's intention that when we do not hear from Imelda for a stretch of time, the movie slows down to a halt.In those long stretches, we yearn for more Imelda on screen. Like the Philippines, we are smitten from the first minute to the last. And suddenly, even with all the horrors that they are responsible for, we realize why the Marcoses keep coming back and back to haunt Filipinos until our dying days.

"The Kingmaker" begins as an unfettered check-in on the life of one of the 20th century's most notorious figures, Imelda Marcos. Like a visit to the zoo, we're granted the opportunity to observe the seemingly self-delusional Marcos in her current habitat as she dreams of a time and place she no longer occupies. Filmmaker Lauren Greenfield allows Imelda the chance to justify, in her own words, her and her late husband's ruthless and corrupt reign as the authoritarian overlords of the Philippines. Greenfield doesn't assist Imelda in her efforts to rewrite history, but she allows Imelda to state her case even as the film mixes in interviews from former friends and enemies (and victims). There are even moments of humor during the film's early-going, as Imelda's obliviousness to the audience's feeling of disgust toward her wastefully lavish and cartoonish lifestyle, cruel indifference for the rights of her fellow countrymen, and insistence on innocence lands perfectly as a joke at the former Filipino First Lady's expense.However, the film transforms into something far uglier and more frightening as Greenfield transitions from mere case study to political exposÃ© (albeit, one that could be a bit more focused). Like watching a horror film, "The Kingmaker" turns the joke around on the Filipino people and the audience. Laugh as you might at Imelda and her seemingly fantastical defenses of the Marcos regime and her pipe dream of seeing her son, BongBong, someday elevated to the presidency, the terrifying and telling reality is that Imelda has not yet been relegated to 20th century has-been. At nearly 90, she's a member of the Filipino House of Representatives, the mother of an influential Filipino senator (her daughter) and a very possible future president (her son), and a behind-the-scenes benefactor of the current authoritarian-leaning president, Rodrigo Dutarte. Delusional though she may be, Imelda is still as cunningly manipulative as ever. Hell, she may be once again controlling the strings of power in the Philippines, more than 30 years after she and her husband were forced into exile. It's the kind of film that sends a chill down your back as the credits roll.

Lauren Greenfield has made films about people with immense wealth before, and both those and her books tend to cover that uncomfortable collision of aspirational wealth and real lived experiences, about little corners of the human psyche (or rather bigger ones in some cases) that desire the glossy fashion spread lifestyle. Imelda Marcos largely fits neatly into that, but with a far bigger and more dangerous political footprint that continues to make itself felt. Ostensibly the title is about her relationship with her husband, the massively corrupt dictator of the Philippines for two decades from the mid-60s to the mid-80s (at which point he was ousted by a 'People Power' revolution via the wife of an assassinated opposition leader, Corazon Aquino), whose power she was said to manipulate for her own ends, most famously for the acquisition of art, designer items and of course shoes. But the film moves quickly on from these trappings to her real and lingering effect on Filipino politics, via her family's dynasty and their support for current dictator-wannabe Rodrigo Duterte. Stylistically it frames Marcos with the opulence of her living spaces, repeatedly showing her handing out money to her loyal supporters crowding around her car or in public appearances (often held and distributed by her staff). She shows off art and photos of her with world leaders (at one point hilariously, but utterly unconcernedly, breaking some of these framed highlights while reaching to show off one, I think with her and Nixon). She is also apparently blithely unaware of how her namedropping comes across, especially when she's talking about aforementioned world leaders or her art collection. She could be a figure of fun, but gradually the film becomes more and more serious about her impact, as it layers on the Marcos's crimes and the real effects of the policies and division they have sowed within the society, paving the way for her and her family's chilling return to power.

I'm pleased to report that this is a far superior and less odiously self-indulgent that Greenfield's Generation Wealth. The Kingmaker starts from a position of curiosity and sympathy (there's something of The Fog of War in Jocelyn Pook's Philip Glassy score); Imelda Marcos as ridiculous but tragic, and maybe misunderstood. The second half of the film morphs into Act of Killing territory and the testimony of victims of the Marcos dictatorship cause the mask to slip. Her attempts to propel her David Brent-like son to power likewise move from mildly pathetic to deeply troubling. Ultimately a film that speaks to a variety of worrying political trends across the world, and how perception trumps truth at all turns.

Really brilliantly constructed - the film sets up as a cosy, cute, harmless portrait of an eccentric celebrity in her grey years, and allows itself to remain in that framework as the body count grows higher, as Kissinger dances on the screen, as the talking heads, initially brought in to provide sappy reminiscing about Imelda's public life, begin to admit propping up dictators for the US' foreign policy interests or detail their sexual assault at the hands of the Marcos regime, as the gormless Jeb Bush-like son goes from affable mummy's boy to a brutal example of the violence of capital exerting itself, and of course as it ends with the still-unfolding nightmare of Duterte. The usefulness of this for the film is that it provides an aesthetic critique of the influence of capital on society by relating everything back to Marcos, in that we see that all its awful violence, its total control over humanity, its manufacturing of poverty and suffering, don't serve some sort of greater noble cause, but instead simply exist so that an elite can buy shoes and completely bizarre confirmations of their self-image. It's useful sometimes to remember how utterly ugly it all is, and how power has no correlation to either intelligence or beauty, it just exerts itself in service of itself - I'd never immediately disbelieve someone who told me the rich devote their whole lives to worshipping Molloch and doing satanic rituals, because there's no need for these things to be real for the idiotic rich to exploit the world in practicing them, as Marcos' obsessive world-mother fantasy and surreal safari island show. The woozy, nightmarish quality of the film's descent into horror doesn't distract from the reality, and it's a serious documentary that isn't reductive to just pointing at the absurdity of the rich. Instead, it uses these contrasts to make the total dominion of capital in public life and its attendant brutality that protects and asserts the power of the dominant elite all the more vivid, and shows how apparently laughable figures like Duterte can exist as the sinew between capitalism and fascism, artificially creating a need and then fulfilling it with a solution that has no alternative (or, a failed neoliberal alternative), like Marcos literally buying the affection of the poor she helped impoverish. It's that clear critique of capital as a structure and empathy for the oppressed throughout that keeps it from being just liberal aesthetic critique, although mockery of the venal rich still has its place - don't let unfunny US talk show hosts take it away from you completely.

Do we feel something when we see Imelda Marcos being pushed around in a wheelchair, or when her memory seems to fail her, or when she betrays some delusion about her place in history? Yes, because we have empathy; unlike some of those currently occupying high office, we're not complete sociopaths. Yet the movie leaves us in little doubt that these most performative signs of weakness - as with any suggestion that Imelda might be considered a victim - may in themselves be a show, a form of spin, and that they are as nothing when one sets them against the lifetime of pain and suffering endured by the Filipino poor. Greenfield induces that wary, guarded empathy one might feel in close proximity to a wounded lion or wolf, creatures that, though laid low, may just rally long enough overnight to make a second lunge for your throat or chest. Even if they can't eat you, their more vigorous offspring still might.

Lauren Greenfield has always had this strange fascination with showing how wealth corrupts people and how excess magnifies eccentricity. I went to an exhibit of hers sometime last year and found it interesting how so many of the portraits were of Imelda Marcos. Imagine my excitement, then, when I found out that the reason behind that was that Greenfield was making a documentary about Imelda. Finally, the wider world would know about the regime that tore our country into pieces. The Kingmaker is mostly successful at that, but it hardly treads new ground. She is portrayed in the documentary like she is portrayed in other international cultural works that feature her: eccentric, charismatic, having led a charmed life, having possessed 3000 shoes. In the end you have to wonder if it's Greenfield who's "tricking" Imelda into making this doc, or it's Imelda who's playing Greenfield.Strangely enough, the section that made it most interesting for me is what probably made it a weaker documentary. There is a 30 minute digression where we hardly see Imelda, and instead focus on the 2016 Vice Presidential elections. The family sees it as a chance to regain power and redeem their name, but their delusions of grandeur and desperation are only magnified. And while Bong Bong Marcos lost the elections, it is apparent that their power only grows stronger with the allegiance of Rodrigo Duterte. It feels less cohesive as a documentary as a result, but at least we're seeing something new. So is it good? I feel it is. Is it enough? Hardly. While there was a heartbreaking series of interviews with Martial Law victims, it is only implied that Imelda Marcos has something to do with this. Why was there no coverage of the convictions in international courts? Why was there no definite statement about the guilt of this woman? The Kingmaker is just another piece of cinema that perpetuates Imelda Marcos's legend. What I want to see is an outright condemnation of this woman, because she deserves nothing less. Never forget.

I've never heard so much aghast tutting in my life as from the audience at this screening. Imelda Marcos was the wife of Ferdinand Marcos, dictator of the Philippines from 1965 to 1986, when she and her husband fled into exile. But in the early 1990s her family returned to the Philippines and in the 2010s began it's return to the frontline of politics, seeking office for her son Bongbong. This film, with a tone of mounting horror, relates their appallingly successful efforts to return to power, the facts as frequently jaw-dropping as they are terrifying. For 90 minutes we watch this despicable cartoon villain throw herself a pity party while others suffer the consequences of her vomit-inducing luxury. The ripest metaphor at the films centre is the safari park she and her husband built, evicting hundreds of families from their island home to make way for animals poached from Africa. The film doesn't quite sell this as a metaphor for the political inbreeding, but it remains an incisive example of the cruelty and selfishness these vile humans spread. The initial catalogue of corruption, fraud, ignorance, exploitation and negligence gradually gives way to the insidious background whispers of genuine atrocities committed, before, in the final act, the curtain is fully drawn back and the extent and immediacy of the consequences of their unquenched thirst for power are lain bare and we finally grasp how urgent and real the threat these people pose democracy truly is. It is the rising panic of witnessing the wave of populism and post-truth over the last half a decade condensed down into 90 minutes. Initial disbelief mixed with a touch of amused mocking scorn, before the prickling sense of unease and ultimate bone chilling realisation that this is our reality now and these people, the worst of humanity, utterly devoid of self-reflection, empathy, intelligence or decency, really are running the world. It's a stunningly effective, if incomplete, account of our nightmare modern reality.

The Kingmaker: Or The Court's FoolSome people say there shouldn't be any platform anymore that would let Imelda Marcos speak. Anything that seems to come out of her mouth serves no higher purpose than to arouse her narcissism as nothing she says adds any real value to what we already know.Squeezing a reasonable statement from her is futile. This documentary would've worked without her. But the thing is: if given the chance for myself, I would've let it all be and made the documentary all about her relishing in her nonsense.No seriously, let me explain. From the cartoonish first shot of Imelda giving bills to the frenzied poor, The Kingmaker had a sense of a mockumentary in it that aims to highlight Imelda's delusions. For a second, I was suspicious about the prospect of this film hellbent on being pro-Imelda propaganda. But then it went somewhere and I realized: the film is not trolling us, it is trolling the Marcos matriarch herself. And in some moments of brilliant comedy, it seems that even she is trolling herself. It looks like I am watching The Office (2005), even though I never did see an episode of The Office. Or a Taika Waititi political satire akin to What We Do In The Shadows (2014), but tyrants instead of vampires, even though I never did see What We Do In The Shadows.By then you ask, "Is this reviewer full of himself? This is the Marcoses we are talking about for crying out loud! None of this is a laughing matter."And so I answer, "Comedy here is so intentional, you must have been an idiot or a hardcore Marcos fanatic to miss it."Greenwood's editing in The Kingmaker is so deliberate in making its subject ridiculous. There are times when scenes should've ended, but then she decides to linger into awkward pauses. Some cuts evoke absurd motifs that elicit restrained laughs. Restrained because they are positioned in instances where the situation programmed you to feel something else.I sure wish the documentary went in this direction completely. Relax, it did go into serious territory. And at this point, the film starts to falter. At least in a self-deprecating mockumentary, you would have focus. Greenwood's fault is that she tried to inject a little bit of everything in the narrative of The Kingmaker hence making the documentary boggled and frustratingly on the fence. It is obviously against tyranny, of course. But then again the documentary could've been appropriated and misread as a loving portrait of the old hag by some people. Which did happen for some appalling reason.By then you ask, "Is a mockumentary more susceptible to misinterpretation?" And so I stubbornly answer, "Shut up. I know. At least we had the unapologetic LOLs."However, as an informative piece that serves as an entry-level lesson to our history, The Kingmaker is highly successful. It even shed light on lesser known controversies that Imelda managed to get her hands on - the Calauit island conversion to an African safari and displacement of its indigenuos people. But you could still accuse the documentary for being pandering to liberals. It portrays the Aquinos as eventual heroes to history, as if the Cory Aquino administration saw significant improvement in the country's atmosphere. Which it didn't, as things arguably went worse.The documentary has an oversimplified black-and-white approach to the subject it tackles that could be a disservice to the complexities of our history, a possible by-product of Greenfield being an outsider.It works for students and foreigners, the latter of which is the real audience of the film. But to people who already made up their minds, there's only so much that this film could do.In a perfect world, The Kingmaker would educate more people on the truth of our history. And it would push loyalists to be more critical of their politics. Hell, in a perfect world, there would've been no need for The Kingmaker. But this isn''t a perfect world. In all seriousness, films like these are noble efforts and should be made more often. Only people should be more critical of what they watch.In lesser seriousness, let me end by cherishing this gem of a scene from the documentary: There's a scene where Imelda recounts how she hid diamonds in diapers to be taken with her as they try to leave MalacaÃ±ang due to the People Power Revolution. "Diamonds in diapers,'' jokes Imelda. Then an awkward pause as she hopes for some laughs in the audience. No one laughed. Then I laughed because no one laughed. â˜†"Perception is real. The truth is not."â˜†It's Women's History Month. Love her or hate her, Imelda Marcos is definitely a woman who made history.In short time I'm going to work my way backwards through documentarian Lauren Greenfield's filmography, starting with her most recent film, The Kingmaker, profiling Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of The Philippines. Notable for far more than just her epic shoe collection, Marcos held the reigns of power behind-the-scenes during her family's time in office, and now has hopes to return to the presidential mansion.Greenfield's style in this film is to allow Marcos to tell her own history and her own story at first. We follow her in-person as she is interviewed, talking about her family, upbringing, and rise to power in the mid-1960s. For over two decades, her husband Ferdinand ruled with her at his side, a political power broker and key agent in diplomacy, using her striking looks and infectious charm to be as close to other world leaders -- often conservative, often dictatorial -- as her husband ever was. Famously catching Ferdinand cheating on her with tape recorder under the bed, which she used as blackmail to get what she wanted later, she grew in prestige and influence into the 80s as the family lived like extravagant royalty amidst a nation suffering in abject poverty. It was the 1986 People Power revolution (and election of Corazon Aquino) which forced them from office and exiled the family from ever ruling The Philippines again.Of course, the Marcos regime ruled with an iron fist in a military dictatorship, and gradually through The Kingmaker the stories of others -- those affected by the imposition of martial law, the families evicted from their homes to the Marcos family could build and renovate at will, the torture victims and political prisoners of innumerable amounts -- come to the fore, and the real truth is revealed about Imelda. That is, Greenfield allows her to be an unreliable narrator, and brings in members of the Aquino family and other opponents to counter her fabrications and exaggerations, like a form of fact checking. Along with her son Bongbong who Imelda wishes to see back in the presidential palace again -- and who probably likes Parasite exactly twice as much as you do -- the two craft a fantastical tale of their birthright to rule, while everyone else fights against their corruption and misdeeds as the loving Marcos clan cozies up to current sociopathic president Duterte.Now in her late 80s, Imelda appears unrepentant and even in denial of any of her family's actions. And why would she admit them? She still maintains fabulous wealth that was shipped offshore and retained after exile, still flaunting it in the face of today's Filipino people and using it to further Bongbong's campaign. In a bizarre state of denial about the years of horror her family brought to The Philippines, Imelda plays the victim and twists the facts to beg for sympathy; unfortunately it has worked in some ways, stealing billions from the country while many Filipinos suffered.Greenfield has explored themes of wealth, privilege, and bewildering ignorance of power and influence before, and The Kingmaker does that effectively. The doc plays with a linear timeline a little, and the shifting stories can make it difficult to follow if you don't already have knowledge of the era. I imagine anyone not from the Philippines and especially anyone under 30 might need more background information about this history to fully grasp the evil of the Marcos regime and impact for decades more, as well as how it's profoundly affected the current Duterte era. This film though is an excellent start.Added to The Best Documentary Films of 2019.Added to Lauren Greenfield ranked.

"They found no skeletons. Only beautiful shoes" is just one of the many striking and unbelievable lines that came from former Philippine First Lady Imelda Marcos in Laura Greenfield's documentary "The Kingmaker". The line exhibits the nonagenarian's lavish perspective despite living in a third world country that suffered from the regime of her late husband and dictator Ferdinand Marcos. Greenfield's documentary shows how "imeldific (ostentatiously extravagant)" the mindset of Imelda despite the numerous human rights violations and embezzlement that happened during the Marcos regime. After all of her controversial past, it is beyond belief how Imelda is firm to declare that the Philippines was in its glory during Martial LawGreenfield portrays Imelda as someone who has a savior complex. Imelda believes that being the first lady means being a mother to everyone so she wants nothing but the best for Filipinos. She visits the streets while aboard her car and gives out money to children. She goes to the hospital and distributes huge bucks like its just coins to her. But being a mother is beyond giving money for Imelda. She wants to convert the country into a paradise that will be looked up by other countries. "The Kingmaker" gives light to the usually undiscussed Calauit Safari Park in Palawan. Imelda was in awe of Africa's beautiful safaris so she bought giraffes, zebras, monkeys, and more African animals and placed them on a small island. The film shows Imelda's inhumane mind when some residents of Calauit island detailed how the military evicted them in favor of the animals that are not even natives in the Southeast Asian Country. It later revealed that the animals there are not properly taken care of because of the absence of a veterinarian who specializes in safari animals. It's an antithesis to Imelda's own perception of being a mother to everything in the Philippines, showing that she's only obsessed with the aesthetic surfaceImelda has also risen to a new societal power when she was shown leading infrastructure projects and buying expensive New York buildings. At some point, it was also suggested that Imelda was the one running the country as her husband is falling ill. "The Kingmaker" shows Imelda as not just a first lady or the "mother" of Filipinos. She is also a puppeteer who can control everyone with the strings made out of Php 1,000 bills.Greenfield was able to show Imelda as an out-of-touch personality who still believes that her family has the solution to everything. However, one has got to ask if Greenfield wants to convince pro-Marcos and moderates to pick the other side. If she has that intention, unfortunately, The Kingmaker" will just serve to them as a "hate piece" to the Marcos supporters and those who are in between. In fact, they may have encountered the 2003 documentary about Imelda but they are still firm on what they believe is right. Moreover, getting Marcos' opponents such as Vice President Leni Robredo and former President Noynoy Aquino (son of slain senator and fierce Marcos critic Benigno Sr.) as the opposing voices to Imelda will more likely fail to convince a lot of people. Hence, the discourse between the Pro- and Anti-Marcos will be just filled with tiring justifications of the authorities' actions."Perception is real and the truth is not," Imelda said in the documentary. So, the question now is "Which perception is Greenfield trying to appeal?". Because if she's appealing to Marcos supporters, the documentary may lack in showing new information on Imelda's ridiculousness. Maybe except for the Calauit safari. The director could have focused her story on that island and meticulously unravel the fate of the residents and the animals there caused by Imelda's shallow vision of a perfect and paradise-like society.
Maybe its only flaw is letting Imelda open her mouth.

I was 10 or 11 years old in 1986 when the Marcos family fled the Philippines. I knew nothing of martial law or potential human rights atrocities. I got my news like everyone else--from Johnny Carson. It was one I was very much looking forward to since it made the rounds at film festivals last year. I never get to go to these festivals, but I try to look at the programming guide and make a schedule as if I was going. I always tried to find room for this film in my make believe schedule. Luckily for me, this film was available as part of a free Showtime weekend on Sling, so my wait wasn't as long as it could have been.I think the film's structure is its biggest obstacle. Not presenting the film mainly in chronological order hurts the storytelling in my opinion. I think that the film would have been better served by showing some present day Imelda then going back to her marriage and really focus on the time of the Marcos presidency/dictatorship. I never really fully grasped the politics of the country based on this documentary. The film kind of jumps around too much to paint a full picture of what was happening to the Filipino people.Perhaps the most egregious part of the film comes at the end titles. There is a lot of interesting information that is thrown up there to read instead of using time to show it on film. We spend a lot of time with Leni Roberdo (who ran against Bongbong Marcos for Vice Presdient), but then learn she suddenly have all of these charges against her by a suspect President! I want to know more about that! Why even bother including it?Despite the, in my opinion, lack of focus the film seems to present, it is compelling to hear the thoughts of Imelda. She remains one of the most infamous people of the late 20th century. But I'm not sure that this film ever allows the viewer to fully know her.

â€œPerception is real, the truth is not.â€Well, ain't that a 2010 quote if ever there was one.The Kingmaker is a documentary about the life and times of one Imelda Marcos, famous First Lady of the Philippines for 21 years. I was generally unaware of her history and her influence going into this, though I'm pretty sure I had an inkling about the shoe thing.The Kingmaker begins innocently enough, starting with Imelda herself. She goes through her history, her upbringing, her marriage, and her pride in the political power she had. She proclaims herself to be "The mother of the nation," a symbol of hope to the masses. People love her, she says, and we're given no reason to think otherwise.Regular documentary viewers may know where this is going; we're being lulled into a false sense of security, before the filmmakers blindside us with a right hook and say, "No, actually, this is how all that really went down."And how. It becomes clear as The Kingmaker goes on that what we're seeing is a portrait of a raging narcissist, an inconsiderate dictator, and, in all likelihood, a mass-murderer. The film is directed by Lauren Greenfield, and while I've not seen any of her previous documentaries, I can tell looking at their descriptions - The Queen of Versailles in 2012, and Generation Wealth in 2018 - that The Kingmaker falls right into her wheelhouse of examining and deconstructing the insanity of the rich and powerful.Right from the start, Imelda Marcos cuts a fascinating, and infuriating, figure. The first thing we see her do in the film is ride around in her luxury limousine, passing by scenes of abject poverty and complaining, "This used to be my little paradise. In my time, there were no beggars." Somehow, I don't believe her. Later, we see her handing out giant wads of money to random passersby. This is something we see her do a bit, and we come to understand it's a regular occurrence; she will frequently walk around, or ride around in busses, handing out money to the impoverished masses, who obviously respond with gratitude. That's how she wins their hearts and minds, see.The film plays a tricky game with Imelda Marcos. Right from the start, we're encouraged to not take her at face value; the film highlights the inherently ridiculous nature of her appeals to mass popularity, and her assurance that she's just as powerful and beloved as she was in her prime, when none of that is clearly true. Basically, she begins the film as a clown, a totally ridiculous figure ripe for mockery. Not knowing the extent of her vileness, I assumed that this was a documentary about how a country was damaged through incompetence.Imelda Marcos begins The Kingmaker as a joke, and ends it as a monster. As the net of the documentary's eye widens, and more and more talking heads emerge to tell their stories of what it was actually like under Marcos dictatorship, the film repeatedly returns to Imelda's silent, resilient gaze, and we're forced to ask: "Surely, there's no way you didn't know about this, right? After all, you were just bragging about how you were the secret power behind your husband. Surely, you knew?"In many ways, The Kingmaker is the perfect documentary for our time. because Imelda Marcos IS a clown; she's a vain, pompous, egotistical fool who at one point insists to the camera that she could've solved all the world's problems, because all the world leaders just found her so charming. But behind all that, there's this twisted image of a frilly despot, lounging away as her country starves, and her people are tortured. By her.The Kingmaker I think does an excellent job at painting Imelda Marcos into a corner from which she can't escape, using cutaway evidence and cross-testimony, all while keeping her unaware that this "puff-documentary" is actually a hit piece. I appreciate that there's never really a moment that The Kingmaker allows her to seem sincere; even when the extent to her monstrosity isn't quite apparent, she comes across as a complete egomaniac, with way too much while her country has way too little.But then things get serious, fast. There are hints as to something darker lurking under the surface early on; how she talks about the period of martial law being a golden age, or how she keeps the body of her husband perfectly preserved behind glass, which is just a horrific image. But then we hear about how she imported all these exotic animals to an island, only to abandon the project after the animals proved to be more trouble than they were worth. Those animals are still there, as cross-breeding catastrophes. We hear about the Tunnel of Love, which was built by Imelda's husband for her, and then became the name of a particularly grisly method of torture. And we follow a series of money trails, the end result of which is that the Marcos family seems to have been robbing their country blind.Even more worryingly, the film will frequently cut to the present, where we see Imelda masterminding her son's campaign to be Vice President of the Philippines (Vice President there is different than in America; it's a separate election than that of the President, and the VP generally has more responsibility than they do here), with the money she seems to have stolen directly from the people. It's here that the film begins to lose me a little; by playing with nonlinear chronology, it sometimes becomes hard to track the exact order of events as they happened. And every once in a while, I did find myself wondering, "I wonder what was happening in the rest of the world at around this time?" But the film does succeed at painting a portrait of wealthy insanity, damningly well. The image of Imelda Marcos, now elderly, on the cusp of re-achieving political dominance and still in complete denial about her family's evil legacy, is appropriately chilling.â€œThere are so many things in the past that we should forget. In fact, itâ€™s no longer there.â€

I'm not super familiar with Laura Greenfield's work, but in my limited knowledge of Generation Wealth and The Queen of Versailles, this is the perfect follow-up to those. I took a course about the history of the Phillippines and while it focused heavily on pre-1900s Phillippines, we, of course, discussed the Marcos regime towards the end of the class. Imelda Marcos is a fascinating character. The Marcos Family itself is just full of heinous characters. Ferdinand Marcos, obviously. But throughout the film, we also learn about Imelda and Bongbong, each awful in their own ways. It's a fascinating look in general at a nation that is going through and has gone through a TON of corruption in its recent history. Imelda is a perfect focus on a documentary like this not just because she is arguably one of the most powerful first ladies in all of the world's modern history, but because she is the perfect snapshot of obscene wealth. Imelda has Monet and Picasso paintings and an obscene amount of shoes and clothes. This all happening in a country that is shown to be going through a significant struggle with many of its citizens facing poverty. What puts this film over the top is that it's well-made. The title, The Kingmaker, refers to Imelda, not just with her husband and how she carried so much power especially socially, but we see her trying to build up her son to become that 'king' of the family in the present day. We also see the Marcos Family trying to make the 'king' of Duterte in order to get Bongbong in power quicker. The aspects of a photography shoot just went on to further highlight Imelda's ridiculous wealth. Perhaps most importantly, though, there is the discussion with opponents of the Marcos power that is able to contradict anything that Imelda may be lying about. This is not a film that glorifies Imelda by any means. It doesn't necessarily deal her a vicious takedown, but rather it gives the audience all the tools we need to make the obvious conclusion that Imelda, despite her sob stories and giving out pity-pay to begging children, is neither a good person, nor worthy of our sympathy.There are tons of incredible and sympathetic characters in this film, though. May Rodriguez's story is truly inspiring. Andy Bautista moving to Oklahoma after investigating Imelda out of fear of Duterte and Marcos is harrowing. "The Kingmaker" is subtle with how it depicts the cunning and devious ways of Imelda Marcos. Actually, it's up to you as the viewer to decide who to side with - Imelda's words or the stories of those who have been oppressed by her family's decisions in the past. Regardless, "The Kingmaker" is a well-balanced documentary that is entertaining as it is cunningly disturbing.It's the 2016 elections and Imelda Marcos is on a mission to make her son Bongbong Marcos the next vice president of the Philippines. Along the way, we get to know the life and the psyche of the woman before she married Ferdinand Marcos, their power during his presidency, and the eventual downfall of their family in 1986 People Power revolution, and their plot to wipe off her family's sinister reputation especially with the younger generation.From its first few minutes, we see Imelda Marcos calm, cool, and collected. Her charm undeniable and even we, as Filipinos, started believing her words. But Lauren Greenfield does amazing work as she subtlety unveils the perceptive reality that Imelda tries to convey against the backdrop of real people who experienced great tragedy through the actions of her and Ferdinand Marcos. The film's tagline uses Imelda's own words that "Perception is real, and the truth is not." is the very real horror in this film. If ever she believes her own lies or lies to the heart to get away with guilt, the truth is that almost everything she started failed to prosper in the long run. It's a reflection of both past wrongs that her family did and the present wrongs that Filipinos are experiencing with its modern politicians. Surprisingly, Lauren Greenfield doesn't force much to assassinate the character of Imelda Marcos as Imelda herself unravels herself. The documentary doesn't really side with any party equally portraying the biases of the other camp. Overall, "The Kingmaker" is a film that every Filipino should watch. This is a really great documentary. On the surface it is a film about the controversial former first lady of the Philippines Imelda Marcos. In reality, though, this film is about something much deeper, an inside look at the troubling dynastic political landscape of the Southeast Asian country. The Marcos presidency was one marked by scandal, corruption, and crime. The film allows Marcos to provide her version of events, her side of the story, but Lauren Greenfield is too smart a filmmaker to allow Marcos to control the narrative. Greenfield is brilliant in how she sets up her scenes, including moments before and after a given 'take' that showcase and highlight Marcos' narcissism and penchant for self indulgence. Greenfield also provides contrasting points of view, footage that provides context, background, and that conflicts with and juxtaposes the words Imelda Marcos spews. This is a woman whose control and corruption are well known and documented, and Greenfield, a director who makes films about the rich and powerful without glorifying their lifestyles but in fact showcasing everything wrong with them, is the person to tell this story.Eventually the film shifts from being a biodoc on Marcus to the current political landscape in the Philippines, Marcos pushing her son to run for president, and the corrupt state of the Filipino political world and how power is constantly transferred between members of the same few families and how little it has to do with the good of the people, who do not factor in at all with the story, they're not even backdrop for the rich, powerful, and influential, and Greenfield makes this abundantly clear. For the Marcos family, and anyone else running the country, it is all about power, wealth, and notoriety and nothing else. Their aspirations are as vacuous as their sense of taste - they accumulate so much, but ultimately all they have to show for it is a lifetime of horrific behavior, crimes against humanity, and a dark soul and evil heart. Bravo Greenfield! This is how you make a doc about someone and make it mean something!

Documentary filmmaker Lauren Greenfield established with THE QUEEN OF VERSAILLES a talent for digging into and laying bare how the obscenely wealthy will stop at nothing in the pursuit for luxurious, expensive goods that make them feel validated in their gilded bubble of privilege. With THE KINGMAKER, Greenfield extends her fascination with this habitual overindulgence to the realm of politics, where a rich person's gluttonous spending and consuming means that money is being denied to a whole lot of people whose welfare the rich person is ostensibly meant to care for. Former First Lady of the Philippines Imelda Marcos is the focus of Greenfield's probing, involving study of despotic decadence, and when we're given a glimpse of a closet housing Marcos' 1,000+ pairs of nice shoes, it's pretty impossible as an American viewer not to think of how our current President once counted a solid gold toilet as one of his prized possessions.As an interview subject, Marcos is more shrewd at polite evasions and even-tempered rationalizations than Trump ever has been, so Greenfield's interviews with Filipino activists, former political prisoners, and other residents end up being more illuminating than her sit-downs with the woman at the film's center. But while the lack of hugely revealing soundbites from Marcos is a flaw of this solid documentary, it's not one that Greenfield should realistically shoulder the blame for. If non-fiction filmmakers focusing on politics were expected to find and interview only wealth-hoarding rulers who are as rivetingly dumb and vicious as Trump is, it's likely they'd never get any work done.

It's pretty crazy how charisma works on many levels. In The Kingmaker, we see explore this through the Marcos regime and its aftermath (and perhaps future).We see Imelda sitting in her apartment, surrounded by the riches and the beauty she always seems to strive for. Some can probably note the piece behind her as something in the style of Picasso, and yes, it is definitely a Picasso. She even proudly confirms this herself.Imelda has a way with words. She interweaves her personal stories with sentiment, nostalgia, and this whole schtick with maternity (I'll get to that later). It's as sugar-coated as it is convincing, especially if you don't know much about the Marcos family or if your Filipino history game is a bit lacking. Outsiders who are out of the loop may sympathise, and the Filipino viewers -- most of who are tired and weary -- may even be captivated by her through their last shred of hope. But this is where it gets good. I really like how Greenfield lets Imelda talk, then juxtaposes it with accounts from multiple people. The selection was very interesting, with the roster including people who sympathise with -- and fought against --the Marcos regime back in those days. It even includes people who are currently in office (at least during the time of this review). Then suddenly you, the viewer, realise that Imelda's words are like a house of cards. My favourite example of this is Calauit Island, where Greenfield not only tells but shows exactly what exactly it had done to both the animals and people who lived there decades later. This style of show-and-perhaps-contradict repeats throughout the documentary, and Greenfield lets it all speak for itself. You, the viewer, doesn't really have to be told outright that Imelda is a narcissist: it just comes out. She tries to hide it around this whole thing about how she is the, and I loosely quote, "mother of the world". That it perfectly justifies the reason why her son should be in power, and how they were actually doing a good thing (this includes her husband's regime). But through the help of the accounts of others, The Kingmaker paints a disturbingly beautiful picture created by the brushstrokes of horror, pain, and struggle that trickles down even in modern Filipino society. While Imelda sits in places of extravagance, and The Kingmaker, does not hesitate in making us remember where exactly all that money came from. A few notes:- Trigger warning on sexual abuse and torture. I was honestly so mad the whole time May Rodriguez was telling her story. I was so mad for her, and mad that she experienced what she did. Sexual abuse is never okay. - @ the guy who had to pick up those glass shards: I see you, and you are valid.- Does require a basic knowledge of who Marcos is and everything. Since this whole doc is mostly focused on Imelda and their lifestyle, it doesn't delve deep into more of the questionable stuff they've done.- I'd say this doc requires a viewer who is open-minded and can look at things objectively. If you are considering to showing this to your nanay, tatay, and other members of the family, I'd say your chances of making them reconsider their stances are 50/50. I found that it's very easy to attach yourself to Imelda + family and ignore everyone else in this doc, especially if your (insert family member here) has an aversion to Leni Robredo -- who shares a decent amount of screen time in this doc.

The Kingmaker is a 2019 documentary film written and directed by Lauren Greenfield, featuring the political career of Imelda Marcos with a focus on the Marcos family's efforts to rehabilitate the family's image and to return to political power, including her plans to see her son Bongbong become President of the Philippines, and the alliance that Bongbong and Imee Marcos established with Rodrigo Duterte in his bid to win the 2016 Philippine presidential election.This documentary lays bare the vile nature of the political strategies deployed by the Marcos family. Ferdinand Marcos is deservedly portrayed as a fascist capitalist dictator. But their greed and lust or power does not stop there. After Ferdinand dies and is denied a funeral in the Philippines, they deploy covert secret strategic tactics to regain power, status and regain their former political reign. They abuse social media to spread lies, use smear campaigns to get back their political power, kill power, oust people who intervene in their plans. The list of vile crimes is endless. I was shocked by the fact that the Philippine people still believed in the Marcos family even after Ferdinand Marcos had 30.000 people killed. For some unknown reason they still vote for Imee Marcos, Ferdinand's daughter, and later on even for Bong Bong, Ferdinand's son. Thd most vile betrayal is the political ruse of letting the people believe that Duterte is a better option than Imelda Marcos. In actuality the Marcos family had struck a deal with Duterte, a former minister in Marcos' government, for the mere purpose of letting Duterte become president. Once Duterte becomes president he removes all those who do not agree with Marcos' views. Duterte when inaugurated acts just like his former co-conspirator Ferdinand Marcos. Hence he kills people. and keeps the people in check by oppression. Duterte even abolishes the PCGG, the committee which works towards getting all the money stolen by Marcos. The leader of the PCGG is charged with corruption and fraud. Similar action are taken against the vice president Robredo. At present, Duterte has imprisoned most people who oppose Marcos. Furthermore, Imee has become a senator in the northern region of the Philippines. Duterte, and the Marcos family are now working towards having Bong Bong inaugurated as the new president of the Philippines. So the evil of the Marcos family is about start all over again.
